Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Respond promptly to emergency calls and reach the scene as quickly as possible
Situation2: A critical call reports a multi-vehicle collision on a highway outside the city.
Story: I was behind the wheel of the ambulance, the radio crackling with urgency as dispatch relayed the details of a multi-vehicle collision on the highway. My heart pounded; every second mattered. As I pulled out of the station, I spotted my stepbrother on the sidewalk, headphones in, eyes glued to his phone. He stepped off the curb, oblivious to the rush of traffic. Instinct screamed at me to stop, to shout, to do anything to keep him safe—after all, I promised our parents I’d always look out for him. But the siren blared, reminding me of the lives depending on my speed, the expectation that I’d reach the accident scene without delay. My hands tightened on the steering wheel, torn between slamming the brakes for my brother or pushing forward for strangers in desperate need. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding something I couldn’t give to the other.
